title: The Commanders are on a winning streak, the best s
text:
The Commanders are on a winning streak, the best since 2006 and their next destination is the Motor City. If you have tickets for the big game Saturday evening, it would be worthwhile to set aside some time to explore a few unique Detroit attractions and restaurants.
The Henry Ford Museum of American Innovation
20900 Oakwood Blvd, Dearborn, MI 48124
thehenryford.org
This is Detroit’s answer to the Smithsonian. Cars, planes, trains, this place has it all. Besides the big game, this may be the highlight of your trip.
Active exhibits include: With Liberty and Justice for All, Driving America and Presidential Vehicles. This exhibit showcases various vehicles, including the horse-drawn carriage utilized by Theodore Roosevelt and the presidential parade cars that transported Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, and George H. W. Bush. Among these, the standout vehicle is the 1961 Lincoln Continental Presidential Limousine, which tragically carried John F. Kennedy during his assassination on November 22, 1963. This vehicle underwent reconstruction and went on to be frequently used by Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard Nixon. Motown Museum
2648 W Grand Blvd, Detroit, MI 48208
motownmuseum.org
Detroit Institute of Arts
5200 Woodward Ave, Detroit, MI 48202
dia.org
The Detroit Institute of Arts is renowned for its exceptional art collection, which is widely regarded as one of the best in the United States. With over 65,000 works, the museum exhibits a diverse range of art, from mummies and modern art to African masks and Monets.
Be sure to visit the Center for African American Art, within the DIA, where you can explore a remarkable gallery featuring 400 pieces created by African American artists in various media. Lafayette Coney Island
118 W Lafayette Blvd, Detroit, MI 48226
American Coney Island
114 W Lafayette Blvd, Detroit, MI 48226
americanconeyisland,com
This is very Detroit, and visitors may be wary to try. Think Ben’s Chili Bowl, kinda. Both Lafayette and American are renowned for their hot dogs, served on steamed buns and topped with chili, onions, and mustard. Located next to each other, locals have a favorite - although it is pretty hard to tell the difference.
The Coney dog has its origins rooted in Greek immigrants who relocated from Coney Island, New York to Detroit during the early 20th century. These immigrants bestowed a Greek touch upon the American hot dog by incorporating a chili sauce infused with traditional Greek spices. Leo’s Coney Island is a favorite if you are staying in the suburbs.
Buddy’s Pizza
1565 Broadway Street, Detroit, MI 48226
buddyspizza.com
Established in 1946, Buddy’s Pizza is renowned for pioneering the Detroit-style square pie. Reminiscent of a Sicilian tomato pizza, this square delicacy features a spongy crust with with crusty, caramelized cheese edges. Toppings, including the sauce go over the cheese.
Stage Deli
6873 Orchard Lake Rd, West Bloomfield Township, MI 48322
stagedeli.com
If you find yourself in the suburbs and craving the authentic flavors of a traditional New York City-style Jewish deli, look no further than the Stage Deli in West Bloomfield. Their offerings, from piled-high corned beef on freshly baked seedless rye, promise an unforgettable experience. Don’t miss out on their latkes and matzo ball soup. The Stage Deli has been serving customers since 1962 and remains a beloved family-owned restaurant. Order ahead for carry-out.
Mike’s Famous Ham Place
3700 Michigan Ave, Detroit, MI 48216
If you are a fan of Virginia ham, then this could be the ideal spot for you to satisfy your cravings while in Detroit. The original lunch counter has proudly stood here since the 1950s, and remarkably, not much has altered throughout the years. The star of the show - ham: whether paired with eggs and toast, on a poppy-seed bun, or covered with split-pea soup. Last year, Mike’s Famous Ham landed on The New York Times’ list of “26 of the Best Dishes We Ate Across the U.S.”
Mexicantown Bakery
4300 Vernor Hwy, Detroit, MI 48209
mexicantownbakery.com
Looking for a sweet treat, be sure to check out Detroit's Mexicantown has been around since the 1920s. A favorite is the Mexicantown Bakery.
